an experimental gas law that describes how the pressure of a gas tends to increase as the volume of the container decreases
one 100th of a meter, equivalent to 0.3937 inch
a combining form meaning “hundredth” or “hundred,” used in the formation of compound words
a temperature scale used by the International System of Units (SI)
a commonly used unit of volume that extends the derived SI-unit cubic meter, and corresponds to the volume of a cube that measures 1 cm × 1 cm × 1 cm
a diagram that show the bonding between atoms of a molecule and the lone pairs of electrons that may exist in the molecule
a measure of the strength of the interaction between the reagents that come together to form the complex
one thousandth of a kilogram
the standard unit of frequency in the International System of Units (SI), equal to one cycle per second
the state or quality of being hard
a theory of gases postulating that they consist of particles of negligible size moving at random and undergoing elastic collisions
an absolute thermodynamic temperature scale using as its null point absolute zero

the standard unit of work or energy in the International System of Units (SI), equal to the work done by a force of one newton when its point of application moves through a distance of one meter in the direction of the force
noting or pertaining to solutions characterized by equal osmotic pressure
the minimum energy that must be provided to detach an electron from the atom of a given element or molecule
the principle that in any closed system subjected to no external forces, the mass is constant irrespective of its changes in form
an SI accepted metric system unit of volume equal to 1 cubic decimeter (dm3), 1,000 cubic centimeter (cm3) or 1/1,000 cubic meter
the integer nearest in value to the atomic weight of an atom and equal to the number of nucleons in the nucleus of the atom
an equation that relates the reduction potential of an electrochemical reaction to the standard electrode potential, temperature, reduction and oxidation
the mass of a molecule
the number of moles of solute per liter of solution
the volume occupied by one mole of a gas, liquid, or solid
a measure of the concentration of a solute in a solution in terms of amount of substance in a specified amount of mass of the solvent
a unit of capacity equal to one thousandth of a liter, and equivalent to 0.033815 fluid ounce, or 0.061025 cubic inch
in the metric system, used in the names of units equal to one thousandth of the given base unit
the standard unit of pressure or stress in the International System of Units (SI), equal to one newton per square meter
any property that is measurable, whose value describes a state of a physical system
a straight line extending from the center of a circle or sphere to the circumference or surface
a graphic representation of the variation with changing temperature of the solubility of a given substance in a given solvent
a type of dynamic equilibrium that exists when a chemical compound in the solid state is in chemical equilibrium with a solution of that compound
an equilibrium constant for the formation of a complex in solution
the standard sets of conditions for measurements
the measure of individual potential of a reversible electrode at standard state, which is with solutes at an effective concentration of 1 mol dm−3, and gases at a pressure of 1 atm
a solution of known concentration, used as a standard of comparison or analysis
a measure of the warmth or coldness of an object or substance with reference to some standard value
the amount of space, measured in cubic units, that an object or substance occupies
the derived unit for electric potential, electric potential difference (voltage), and electromotive force
a universal physical constant important in many areas of physics
rapidity of motion or operation; swiftness; speed
the pressure exerted by the molecules of a vapor, especially that part of the total pressure exerted by vapor in a mixture of gases, as by water vapor in air
an impact of the change in the equilibrium constant, of a chemical reaction to the change in temperature, given the standard enthalpy change
a distance-dependent interactions between atoms or molecules
any magnitude regarded as an independent whole; a single, indivisible entity
any of a variety of mathematical inequalities asserting a fundamental limit to the precision with which certain pairs of physical properties of a particle can be known
the distance over which the wave's shape repeats
a distance traversed by a periodic, or cyclic, motion per unit time (in any direction)
the amount or quantity of heaviness or mass; amount a thing weighs
